content.question: ​In a certain nuclear chain reaction, the number of atoms increases. At time <math alttext="700"><semantics><mn>700</mn><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> milliseconds since the start of the reaction, there are about <math alttext="1500"><semantics><mn>1500</mn><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> atoms, and at time <math alttext="770"><semantics><mn>770</mn><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> milliseconds, there are about <math alttext="3000"><semantics><mn>3000</mn><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> atoms. Using a logarithmic regression, a model <math alttext="T"><semantics><mi>T</mi><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> is constructed, where <math alttext="T open parentheses x close parentheses equals a plus b ln x"><semantics><mrow><mi>T</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>ln</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> gives the time, in milliseconds, at which there are <math alttext="x"><semantics><mi>x</mi><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> atoms. Which of the following best approximates the number of milliseconds it will take for the number of atoms to reach <math alttext="10 , 000"><semantics><mn>10,000</mn><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> ?

topic.text: 2.14: Logarithmic Function Context and Data Modeling

skill.text: Skill 3.B: Apply numerical results in a given mathematical or applied context.
